facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

question.question: What are the specific contributions of Chris North and Alex Endert to the field of sensemaking, as reflected in the titles and abstracts of their papers from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Filter papers by authors Chris North and Alex Endert
authors_of_interest = ['Chris North', 'Alex Endert']
filtered_df = df[df['AuthorNames'].apply(lambda x: any(author in x for author in authors_of_interest))]

# Filter papers by year range 2010 to 2012
filtered_df = filtered_df[(filtered_df['Year'] >= 2010) & (filtered_df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract relevant information
contributions = filtered_df[['Year', 'Title', 'Abstract', 'AuthorNames']]

# Print the contributions
print("### Begin of facts")
for index, row in contributions.iterrows():
    print(f"Year: {row['Year']}")
    print(f"Title: {row['Title']}")
    print(f"Abstract: {row['Abstract'][:150]}...")  # Print first 150 characters of abstract for brevity
    print(f"Authors: {row['AuthorNames']}")
    print("---")
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

question.question: What are the specific contributions of Chris North and Alex Endert to the field of sensemaking, as reflected in the titles and abstracts of their papers from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Filter papers by authors Chris North and Alex Endert
authors_of_interest = ['Chris North', 'Alex Endert']
filtered_df = df[df['AuthorNames'].apply(lambda x: any(author in x for author in authors_of_interest))]

# Filter papers by year range 2010 to 2012
filtered_df = filtered_df[(filtered_df['Year'] >= 2010) & (filtered_df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract relevant information
contributions = filtered_df[['Year', 'Title', 'Abstract', 'AuthorNames']]

# Print the contributions
print("### Begin of facts")
for index, row in contributions.iterrows():
    print(f"Year: {row['Year']}")
    print(f"Title: {row['Title']}")
    print(f"Abstract: {row['Abstract'][:150]}...")  # Print first 150 characters of abstract for brevity
    print(f"Authors: {row['AuthorNames']}")
    print("---")
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

    print(f"Authors: {row['AuthorNames']}")
    print("---")
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset

# Filter papers by authors Chris North and Alex Endert
authors_of_interest = ['Chris North', 'Alex Endert']
filtered_df = df[df['AuthorNames'].apply(lambda x: any(author in x for author in authors_of_interest))]

# Filter papers by year range 2010 to 2012
filtered_df = filtered_df[(filtered_df['Year'] >= 2010) & (filtered_df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract relevant information
contributions = filtered_df[['Year', 'Title', 'Abstract', 'AuthorNames']]

# Print the contributions
print("### Begin of facts")

    print(f"Year: {row['Year']}")
    print(f"Title: {row['Title']}")
    print(f"Abstract: {row['Abstract'][:150]}...")  # Print first 150 characters of abstract for brevity
    print(f"Authors: {row['AuthorNames']}")
    print("---")
print("### End of facts")

question.question: How has the frequency of the keyword 'sensemaking' in research titles and abstracts changed over the years in the dataset?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Function to count occurrences of 'sensemaking' in a text
count_sensemaking = lambda text: text.lower().count('sensemaking')

# Calculate the frequency of 'sensemaking' in titles and abstracts
df['SensemakingCount'] = df['Title'].apply(count_sensemaking) + df['Abstract'].apply(count_sensemaking)

# Group by year and sum the counts
yearly_sensemaking = df.groupby('Year')['SensemakingCount'].sum().reset_index()

# Plot the trend over the years
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(yearly_sensemaking['Year'], yearly_sensemaking['SensemakingCount'], marker='o')
plt.title("Frequency of 'Sensemaking' in Research Titles and Abstracts Over the Years")
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Frequency of Sensemaking')
plt.grid(True)
plt.xticks(yearly_sensemaking['Year'])
plt.show()

insights: The dataset includes research papers from 2010, 2011, and 2012, all of which mention 'sensemaking' in their abstracts, indicating a consistent interest in the topic over these years.

In 2010, the paper titled 'Diamonds in the rough: Social media visual analytics for journalistic inquiry' discusses sensemaking in the context of social media and journalism, suggesting an early exploration of sensemaking in digital media environments.

By 2012, the paper 'Semantic Interaction for Sensemaking: Inferring Analytical Reasoning for Model Steering' indicates a more developed focus on sensemaking, particularly in relation to user interaction and visual analytics, showing an evolution towards integrating human reasoning with computational models.

The 2011 paper 'Observation-level interaction with statistical models for visual analytics' also emphasizes sensemaking, particularly through interaction with statistical models, highlighting a trend towards more interactive and user-centered approaches in visual analytics.

question.question: Who are the most frequently mentioned authors in the dataset, and how are they connected to the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012?

facts.code:
import pandas as pd
from collections import Counter

# Load the dataset
path = 'outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(path)

# Extract authors and years
authors = df['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
years = df['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author
author_counts = Counter(authors)

# Get the most frequently mentioned authors
most_frequent_authors = author_counts.most_common(5)

# Analyze the evolution of sensemaking research from 2010 to 2012
sensemaking_papers = df[df['Title'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False) | df['Abstract'].str.contains('sensemaking', case=False)]
sensemaking_authors = sensemaking_papers['AuthorNames'].str.split(';').explode()
sensemaking_years = sensemaking_papers['Year']

# Count the frequency of each author in sensemaking papers
sensemaking_author_counts = Counter(sensemaking_authors)

print("### Begin of facts")
print("Most frequently mentioned authors:")
for author, count in most_frequent_authors:
    print(f"{author}: {count} times")

print("\nAuthors involved in sensemaking research (2010-2012):")
for year in range(2010, 2013):
    authors_in_year = sensemaking_authors[sensemaking_years == year]
    author_counts_in_year = Counter(authors_in_year)
    print(f"Year {year}:")
    for author, count in author_counts_in_year.items():
        print(f"  {author}: {count} times")

print("### End of facts")

question.question: What are the specific contributions of Chris North and Alex Endert to the field of sensemaking, as reflected in the titles and abstracts of their papers from 2010 to 2012?

import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv('outputs/simple_iteration/thread_20250815_023920/dataset_selected.csv')

# Filter papers by authors Chris North and Alex Endert
authors_of_interest = ['Chris North', 'Alex Endert']
filtered_df = df[df['AuthorNames'].apply(lambda x: any(author in x for author in authors_of_interest))]

# Filter papers by year range 2010 to 2012
filtered_df = filtered_df[(filtered_df['Year'] >= 2010) & (filtered_df['Year'] <= 2012)]

# Extract relevant information
contributions = filtered_df[['Year', 'Title', 'Abstract', 'AuthorNames']]

# Print the contributions
print("### Begin of facts")
for index, row in contributions.iterrows():
    print(f"Year: {row['Year']}")
    print(f"Title: {row['Title']}")
    print(f"Abstract: {row['Abstract'][:150]}...")  # Print first 150 characters of abstract for brevity
    print(f"Authors: {row['AuthorNames']}")
    print("---")
print("### End of facts")
